name: Probability Theory for Computer Scientists

prereqs.text: ((21-112 [] at least D) and (21-111 [] at least D)) or (21-120 [] at least D) or (21-256 [] at least D) or (21-259 [] at least D)

long_desc: Probability theory is the mathematical foundation for the study of both statistics and of random systems. This course is an intensive introduction to probability,from the foundations and mechanics to its application in statistical methods and modeling of random processes. Special topics and many examples are drawn from areas and problems that are of interest to computer scientists and that should prepare computer science students for the probabilistic and statistical ideas they encounter in downstream courses and research. A grade of C or better is required in order to use this course as a prerequisite for 36226, 36326, and 36410. If you hold a Statistics primaryadditional major or minor you will be required to complete 36226. For those who do not have a major or minor in Statistics, and receive at least a B in 36218, you will be eligible to move directly onto 36401.

custom_fields.goals: Students will be able to calculate probabilities using known and unknown parameters, describeidentifytransformmanipulate probability distributions, work with random variables, use standard estimation approaches for inference, and implement nonparametric techniques e.g., smoothing, bootstrapping, etc..
custom_fields.key_topics: Probability theory, random variables, joint/conditional distributions, the law of large numbers, the central limit theorem, smoothing, regression, maximum likelihood estimation, bootstrapping.
custom_fields.prerequisite_knowledge: Univariate calculus (differentiation & integration); multivariable calculus would be preferred.
custom_fields.assessment_structure: Assignments, exams, and a final exam.
custom_fields.relevance: Develop an understanding of probability theory that serves as a foundation for the statistical modeling of random phenomena as well as inferential tools used for estimation. Applications will be specifically tailored towards scenarios relevant to computer science.
custom_fields.learning_resources: Lecture slides, case studies, textbooks, websites, articles, and sample code.
